ai_page.title: Apply to make change to a council flat - Slough - Page
ai_page.body:
Making improvements to your council home

Before secure housing tenants can make changes and improvements to their home, they must ask for council permission. Changes you must ask us for permission for include:

  • building sheds, garages and greenhouses or putting up extra fencing
  • building an extension or conservatory
  • making changes to your garden, like constructing a pond or concreting over it
  • making changes to the electrics.

Download the request permission to make a change to your council home form.

We give permission for most home improvements, but often attach conditions which usually include you agreeing to:

  • use a competent contractor and complete the work to an acceptable standard
  • a time limit for completing the work
  • submit plans for the work
  • get building regulations approvals and planning permission
  • tell us when you’ve finished the work so we can inspect it
  • provide us with copies of certificates including electrical and building regulations.

Getting the right permissions to make changes

To make changes to your council home you must:

  • complete the permission form to get written permission from Slough Borough Council
  • check if you need to apply for planning permission
  • check if you need a building regulation application.

If you carry out any changes without permission, you will have to pay to return the property to its original condition. If you do not pay, we will have the work done and recharge you.

If permission is given to make changes

Once you have all the right permissions, you can go ahead with the work. Depending on the scale of improvements, we may want to inspect your home before and after. You are responsible for repairing and maintaining any home improvement you make.

If you get a contractor to do the work, make sure the contractor has disposed of the rubbish correctly. Fly-tipping is a crime. If you are doing the work, dispose of your waste properly.

If permission to make changes is refused

Permission to make changes will be refused if we have a good reason. We normally prevent changes if the work will affect the safety of your building, cause a future problem with maintenance of the property, or cause nuisance to your neighbour/s.

Refusals are communicated to you in writing, either by post or email. If you disagree with our decision or the conditions we have attached, you can appeal in a letter to us.

ai_business_case.title: Apply to make change to a council flat - Slough - Business Case
ai_business_case.letter:
Dear CEO,

As the usability lead responsible for enhancing our online service experience, I have reviewed the customer persona, feedback, and current web content related to applying for permission to make changes to council flats. Based on this analysis, I recommend targeted improvements to streamline the process, improve user understanding, and reduce administrative burdens, ultimately resulting in cost savings and better service efficiency.

Observation and Insights:
- The customer persona, David, is comfortable with digital interfaces and values clear, step-by-step guidance that minimizes uncertainty.
- The existing content communicates necessary legal and procedural information effectively but contains areas where clarity and user engagement can be significantly improved.
- The current feedback indicates that the instructions are sometimes passive or complex, which may cause confusion or hesitation among users like David.

Recommended Improvements:
1. Enhance Call-to-Action Clarity:
- Replace passive instructions such as "Download the request permission to make a change to your council home form" with a direct call-to-action, e.g., "Download the Permission Request Form."
- Impact: Clear, actionable prompts improve user comprehension and reduce the likelihood of incomplete or incorrect submissions, decreasing follow-up queries and administrative overhead.

2. Simplify and Clarify Language:
- Rephrase "Changes you must ask us for permission for include" to "Changes that require our permission include:"
- Impact: Simplified language reduces cognitive load, encouraging timely customer engagement and decreasing support requests.

3. Emphasize the Process:
- Add guidance such as "Before starting any work, ensure you have obtained all necessary permissions. You can check the requirements here [link]."
- Impact: Encourages customers to verify permissions early, preventing unauthorized work and potential costly rework or legal issues.

4. Incorporate Progress Indicators and FAQs:
- Introduce visual cues showing processing stages or estimated timelines, and quick links to common questions.
- Impact: Increases customer confidence, reduces anxiety about delays, and streamlines communication, cutting down on customer service inquiries.

Summary:
Implementing these targeted refinements will make the application process more intuitive for users like David, encouraging correct and complete submissions the first time. This will reduce manual intervention and administrative costs, improve service turnaround times, and enhance the overall satisfaction of our tenants.

I recommend prioritizing these usability enhancements on our platform to support our commitment to accessible, efficient, and cost-effective services.

Respectfully,

[Your Name]
Web Usability Lead
